Author: PHBA2061#2530
Content:
yesterday I started to play around with tokens, but on MORTY instead.
was also thinking about adding images, I see 2 ways:
-either adding the images url directly to the tokens description
-or use an existing back-end API, extract images out of it based on the tokens ID.
btw tokens that I created on MORTY are Pok√©mon, & I'll use a Pok√©mon api to attach images to them

Author: gcharang#6833
Content:
if you go with adding images via url, make sure to include a sha256 hash
it should help detect tampering  

I didn't quite get the second option?

Author: PHBA2061#2530
Content:
for example this is the PIKACHU token that I created yesterday on MORTY:
```
komodo-cli -ac_name=MORTY tokeninfo "fc658af6364f80f76f7ef92e18303ebae91b8d076757c624c7653710a7887b29"
{
  "result": "success",
  "tokenid": "fc658af6364f80f76f7ef92e18303ebae91b8d076757c624c7653710a7887b29",
  "owner": "03f6bd15dba7e986f0c976ea19d8a9093cb7c989d499f1708a0386c5c5659e6c4e",
  "name": "PIKACHU",
  "supply": 6,
  "description": "{\"id\":\"25\",\"name\":Pikachu}"
}
```
for this example only id & name are stored on chain, from the id/name on chain, which can can get via `curl`, I can fetch it into an API like 
```
https://pokeapi.glitch.me/v1/pokemon/Pikachu
```
& retrieve additional data out of it, including images.
ofc you have to decide which one to store on chain, which one to store off chain.

Author: gcharang#6833
Content:
now I understand the second option
anyway, including the hash in the description is a good idea
like
```json
"{\"id\":\"25\",\"name\":Pikachu,\"hash\":\"6b86b273ff34fce19d6b804eff5a3f5747ada4eaa22f1d49c01e52ddb7875b4b\"}"
```

Author: CrisF#3405
Content: Hi @PHBA2061, With the second option, how would you wiew the image?

Author: PHBA2061#2530
Content: yeah including the hash makes sense

Author: gcharang#6833
Content: the gui dev should know which base url the token is using for images

Author: PHBA2061#2530
Content: @CrisF once you have the API (either setting 1 up yourself or in this case I use an existing API), you can make a simple API fetch with the pok√©mon name as parameter, then retrieve the image url return by the API, display it on the website. I think I'll be dev-ing a demo real soon

Author: gcharang#6833
Content:
@PHBA2061 if you are looking to minimise space taken on the blockchain, you can also store the data as
```
'["25","Pikachu","6b86b273ff34fce19d6b804eff5a3f5747ada4eaa22f1d49c01e52ddb7875b4b"]'
```
no need to mention the keys: id, name, hash

Content:
`including the hash in the description`
Is this the hash of the image?

Author: gcharang#6833
Content:
> Is theis the hash of the image?
yes
if the image at the url is changed, it can be detected

Author: PHBA2061#2530
Content: `no need to mention the keys: id, name, hash` agreed

Author: PHBA2061#2530
Content:
the API call I post above is just 1 example with Pikachu as parameter, the full documentation of that API can be found here:
<https://pokedevs.gitbook.io/pokedex/resources/pokemon#example-request>
you can replace Pikachu by something else & give it a try

Author: PHBA2061#2530
Content: and these are just data returned by the API, how to represent those data is up to the front-end dev

Author: CrisF#3405
Content: What would be the main advantages / disadvantages between method 1 and 2?

Author: PHBA2061#2530
Content: method 1: in general if you store a value on chain, it's non modifiable, . method 2: the value is stored off chain, so it's modifiable, but if you store too many things on chain, the chain can be bloated. So you need to consider between storing on chain or off chain.

Author: CrisF#3405
Content: I'm very interested to see this in action :2561_feelsevilman:

Author: PHBA2061#2530
Content: me too üòÑ

Author: CrisF#3405
Content: Is this data (https://pokeapi.glitch.me/v1/pokemon/Pikachu) part of the API, or is it just data that the API connects the token to?

Author: PHBA2061#2530
Content: that is part of the API.

Author: CrisF#3405
Content: Thanks.  Those simple questions are very hard for me to find an answer to with google :abusedsmily:

Author: PHBA2061#2530
Content: yeah it might be confused at first but don't worry

Author: PHBA2061#2530
Content: <https://pokeapi.glitch.me/v1/pokemon/Pikachu> basically returned data about Pikachu stored on a centralized server run by someone

Author: CrisF#3405
Content: Thanks, I wasn't sure if the data itself, or server were part of the API. (Or if the API is only the link).

Author: PHBA2061#2530
Content: in short, the back-end server has some code running on it (imagine it's like komodo daemon), API are the set of instructions that allow you to interact with the back-end (like how you run `komodo-cli help` or `komodo-cli getbalance` to interact with komodo daemon, but in this case you interact with the back-end via `https://pokeapi.glitch.me/v1/pokemon/Pikachu` or `https://pokeapi.glitch.me/v1/pokemon/25` instead)

Author: CrisF#3405
Content: Thanks, @PHBA2061.  That's exactly what I wanted to know. üôá

Author: CrisF#3405
Content:
*For KB* üëá``` Attaching Data to Tokens

We can attach meta data to the tokens at their creation.

The maximum size of data that can fit in a single Komodo transaction is 10000 bytes. This is enough to include all sorts of data, and even simple images.

The developer is naturally free to use their imagination in the design of this data. For example, you can describe their purpose and add a json data structure that informs other software of the properties of this token.

Advanced developers can even add functionality to allow the tokens to gain new data over time as they are passed through transactions.```
